Smith (2020:360) explains the nasality with an excrescent nasal and lists as similar examples Javanese əntut, Tontemboan əntut, Palauan ʔolð, Malay kəntut (all from *qəntut) as well as Toba untut and Simalungan untut (all from *quntut)

Smith (2020:359) proposes a vocative suffix *-ŋ to account for nasalization and lists as cognates Tagalog amá-ŋ 'elder person', Bidayuh amaŋ 'father', Toba Batak amáŋ 'oh father' and Totoli amaŋ 'father'

final /dui/ probably from e-dui ‘thorn, spike’ < *duRi, spelled pũnũ/pũrũ in Nothofer (1994:402), reconstructed Proto-Paleo-Hesperonesian *buluŋ 'leaf' (Nothofer 1994:402), cited Isneg buloŋ, Ilocano bulóŋ as cognates
